caption: Table 1: Advantages of GATSM.
description: This table compares the capabilities of GATSM with existing GAMs and NATM across three key aspects: handling time series input, capturing temporal patterns, and supporting dynamic time series.  It highlights GATSM's ability to address the limitations of existing methods by successfully incorporating all three features.

caption: Table 2: Dataset statistics.
description: This table presents the characteristics of the eight time series datasets used in the paper's experiments.  It shows whether the time series have variable lengths, the number of time series in each dataset, the average length of the time series, the number of features, and the number of classes (for classification tasks).  These statistics provide context for understanding the experimental results and the complexity of the datasets used.

caption: Table 3: Predictive performance comparison of various models.
description: This table presents a comparison of the predictive performance of 12 baseline models and the proposed GATSM model across eight different datasets.  The performance metrics used depend on the type of task (forecasting or classification), and include R-squared (R2) for forecasting tasks and AUROC/Accuracy for classification tasks. The table shows the mean score and standard deviation across five different random seeds for each model and dataset.  The best-performing model for each dataset is highlighted in bold, and the second-best is underlined. This table allows for a direct comparison of the proposed model against a wide range of existing models, providing evidence of its effectiveness.

caption: Table 4: Ablation study on different feature functions.
description: This table presents the ablation study results on different feature functions used in GATSM.  It compares the performance of GATSM when using linear, NAM, and NBM feature functions across eight different datasets. The results show how the choice of feature function impacts model performance, demonstrating the effectiveness of the NBM approach used in GATSM.

caption: Table 3: Predictive performance comparison of various models.
description: This table presents a comparison of the predictive performance of different machine learning models on eight real-world time series datasets.  The models are categorized into four groups: black-box tabular models, black-box time series models, transparent tabular models, and transparent time series models. The performance metrics used depend on the type of task (forecasting or classification) for each dataset and include R2 scores for forecasting tasks and AUROC/accuracy scores for classification tasks.  The table allows for a comparison of the predictive performance across different model types and datasets.

caption: Table 6: Optimal hyper-parameters for GATSM.
description: This table shows the optimal hyperparameters found by using Optuna for each dataset used in the paper.  The hyperparameters are specific to the Generalized Additive Time Series Model (GATSM) and were determined through a hyperparameter search process using the Tree-structured Parzen Estimator (TPE) algorithm. The table includes the batch size, whether batch normalization was used in the Neural Basis Model (NBM), the dropout rate for the NBM, the embedding size for the attention mechanism, the number of attention heads, the attention dropout rate, the learning rate, and the weight decay. The values shown are the optimal settings identified for each dataset after 100 trials of hyperparameter optimization.

caption: Table 7: Inference throughput of different models.
description: This table presents the inference speed (throughput) of various models on eight different datasets.  The throughput is measured in units of data points processed per second (K for thousands and M for millions). The table compares the inference speed of GATSM to various baselines, including other transparent models and black-box time series models like Transformer.  This allows a comparison of inference speed while considering factors like the model's complexity and the number of features in each dataset.
